title: Age-related changes in low-level inhibitory control
abstractText: A crucial aspect of understanding normal ageing, and an essential prerequisite for any development aimed at improving quality of life in old age, is to understand how cognitive functions are affected by normal ageing. A recent influential theory has suggested that many age-related cognitive deficits might be due to impaired inhibitory mechanisms. Three studies are planned to investigate the impact of old age on low-level, non-voluntary perceptuo-motor control mechanisms. Mainly employing the 'masked prime' paradigm, our main objectives will be to (1) assess the extent to which low-level control is influenced by older adults' perceptual limitations and/or generally slower processing; (2) investigate the effect of old age on each of the component processes involved (activation, inhibition, and disinhibition); and (3) explore the relationship between low-level inhibitory motor control and top-down cognitive control processes in older adults. The results are expected to provide insight into some of the most fundamental mechanisms underlying normal age-related performance deficits by illuminating the extent to which low-level inhibitory motor control is impaired in old age, and the extent to which such impairment correlates with and contributes to the overall age-related decline in cognitive performance.
